metadata.title: Building a simple Python application with Google Trends | by Dan Root | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: Building a simple Python application with Google Trends
metadata.description: Excel is a Microsoft product that is very commonly used in professional settings, as well as for educational and personal workflows. It should be no surprise if you run into this application as a…

all_paragraphs: Excel is a Microsoft product that is very commonly used in professional settings, as well as for educational and personal workflows. It should be no surprise if you run into this application as a Python programmer. Depending on what you are programming, it may be handy to know more about how to interact with excel files in Python.
Google Trends tracks search analytics for the Google Search Engine. We will use an unofficial API named pytrends to get the data we need for this project.

I will get keyword data from Google Trends and then I will display the data in Microsoft Excel. I will use the tkinter module to give the user a nice GUI (Graphical User Interface) to input the search word. I will be using PyCharm Professional for this project.
If you are new to Python, I advise reading some other articles I’ve written to get you the basic knowledge you will need for this tutorial.
Also, I will include my GitHub Repository for this project here.

So, we are going to build a Python application that takes a word as an input by a user and outputs the related Google Keyword Suggestions in a report format on an excel file that automatically pops up for the user’s convenience.

Okay, so to start off I am going to start a new project in PyCharm. I will also be using the files keywords.xlsx and logo_image.png. These files can be found in my GitHub Repo. I will use a standard Python virtual environment. I will be using the pytrends unofficial API, as stated earlier. Remember to install any package dependencies for the project now.
First, I will do my imports.
Next, I will want to build a class.
Then I will define the newWindow() method.
Now I will define the excelWriter() method nested in the newWindow() method.

After that I define the button and link it to the excelWriter() method via the command= parameter when calling Button() outside and after the nested excelWriter() method, but still within the newWindow() method.
Now we go back up within the __init__() function at the beginning of the code for the class and call the newWindow() method. Remember to use the keyword self to reference the method correctly.
To complete the program, at the end of the code in global scope (not belonging to any code block) call the MyKeywordApp() class.
That is it. If you run the application it should pop a window up like this:
Just input a word and submit it by clicking the Run Report button. An excel file will open containing Google Suggested Keywords for that search word in a report format.

This was meant to be an introductory walkthrough to get started with Python projects involving Microsoft Excel, Google Trends, and tkinter. Thank you for reading and I hope this helps anyone looking to get started with projects like this. If you have any comments, questions, or corrections I encourage you to post them in the response section below. Thank you for reading and happy coding!
